div1.p: Wilson enjoyed reading Hench's "Conquerors of Yellow Fever" and suggests having it published.

div1.head: Letter from W.F. Wilson to Philip Showalter Hench, December 29, 1941
div1.p:
DR. W. F. WILSON
LAKE CITY, MINNESOTA December, 29, 1941.??? P. S. Hench, M.D.
Rochester, Minn.

After reading “Conquerors of Yellow Fever” in the Dec. 10
issue of the Proceedings", I felt I must write and ask if more pub-
licity to the laity could not be given this article.

The acts you describe and that are memorialized in the
painting, certainly constitute a real “epoch” in the progress of
medicine and the progress of mankind. Think of the lives saved
due to the researches and discoveries of that group of men,- and
not only that but the vast changes in history and geography.
Reclaiming previously uninhabitable parts of the earth, and permit-
ting vigorous bodies and keen, bright intellects in the debilitating
tropics, is certainly something epochal.

With all due respect to the large book by Helen Clapes-
attle portraying the achievements of “The Doctors Mayo”, there is
more dramatic discovery represented in your article.

It may be that you and Dr. Louis Wilson have considered
this matter. I am sure if you send a copy of the Proceedings or
a reprint to the Reader's Digest" Pleasantville, N. Y. they will
probably give space to the whole article, or at least a condensation.
I suggest this publication because of its widespread circulation.
Pardon the presumption, but it is well meant

December 30, 1941 Dr. J. F. Rodriguez Perez
Director de la Seccion de Publicaciones
Cientificas y Biblioteca
Instituto Finlay
Habana, Cuba

I have just received a letter from Senor Garcia of the Alabama
Studios, dated December 19, sending me a photograph of Hospital No. 1 and
offering to return the remainder of my check as he understands that you
have already had a copy of the book made for me to be sent to me with the
compliments of the Finlay Institute. I do not know whether this is a
mistake or not. Maybe it is and maybe the young lady who translated the
letter for me here made a mistake. Your letter of a few days ago said
you were making the copy for the Surgeon General's library in Washington
and I know they will be delighted to have this. If perhaps you have had
an extra copy made for me I shall be most grateful to receive it whether
I pay for it or not.

In any event, I am exceedingly anxious to have this within the
next few days when I go to Washington, leaving here on January 8. If I
could receive it here before then I would be glad to have it. Otherwise,
perhaps it could be mailed to reach me in Washington in care of the Willard
Hotel where I will arrive January 13.
